intro: Ranunculus flabellatus proles dimorphorrhizus, commonly known as the two-rooted water buttercup, is a rare and specialized aquatic plant native to specific wetland habitats in southern Africa. It is characterized by its distinctive yellow flowers with five petals and its unique dimorphic root system, which consists of both fibrous and rhizomatous roots. The plant thrives in still or slow-moving freshwater environments, often found in marshes and along the edges of ponds. Its leaves are submerged, while its flowering stems rise to the surface, allowing for efficient photosynthesis. Due to its limited distribution and specific ecological requirements, it is considered a vulnerable species requiring conservation efforts to ensure its survival.
